00015  * The order of the series relating \e s and \e sigma when expanded in powers
00016  * of \e k1.

00018 #define GEOD_TAU_ORD \
00019 (sizeof(real) == sizeof(double) ? 5 : sizeof(real) == sizeof(float) ? 4 : 6)

00037   /**
00038    * \brief %Geodesic calculations
00039    *
00040    * The shortest path between two points on a ellipsoid at (\e lat1, \e lon1)
00041    * and (\e lat2, \e lon2) is called the geodesic.  Its length is \e s12 and
00042    * the geodesic from point 1 to point 2 has azimuths \e azi1 and \e azi2 at
00043    * the two end points.  (The azimuth is the heading measured clockwise from
00044    * north.  \e azi2 is the "forward" azimuth, i.e., the heading that takes you
00045    * beyond point 2 not back to point 1.)
00046    *
00047    * If we fix the first point and increase \e s12 by \e ds12, then the second
00048    * point is displaced \e ds12 in the direction \e azi2.  Similarly we
00049    * increase \e azi1 by \e dazi1 (radians), the the second point is displaced
00050    * \e m12 \e dazi1 in the direction \e azi2 + 90<sup>o</sup>.  The quantity
00051    * \e m12 is called the "reduced length" and is symmetric under interchange
00052    * of the two points.  On a flat surface, he have \e m12 = \e s12.  The ratio
00053    * \e s12/\e m12 gives the azimuthal scale for an azimuthal equidistant
00054    * projection.
00055    *
00056    * Given \e lat1, \e lon1, \e azi1, and \e s12, we can determine \e lat2, \e
00057    * lon2, \e azi2, \e m12.  This is the \e direct geodesic problem.  (If \e
00058    * s12 is sufficiently large that the geodesic wraps more than halfway around
00059    * the earth, there will be another geodesic between the points with a
00060    * smaller \e s12.)
00061    *
00062    * Given \e lat1, \e lon1, \e lat2, and \e lon2, we can determine \e azi1, \e
00063    * azi2, \e s12, \e m12.  This is the \e inverse geodesic problem.  Usually,
00064    * the solution to the inverse problem is unique.  In cases where there are
00065    * muliple solutions (all with the same \e s12, of course), all the solutions
00066    * can be easily generated once a particular solution is provided.
00067    *
00068    * As an alternative to using distance to measure \e s12, the class can also
00069    * use the arc length \e a12 (in degrees) on the auxiliary sphere.  This is a
00070    * mathematical construct used in solving the geodesic problems.  However, an
00071    * arc length in excess of 180<sup>o</sup> indicates that the geodesic is not
00072    * a shortest path.  In addition, the arc length between an equatorial
00073    * crossing and the next extremum of latitude for a geodesic is
00074    * 90<sup>o</sup>.
00075    *
00076    * The calculations are accurate to better than 15 nm.  (See \ref geoderrors
00077    * for details.)
00078    *
00079    * For more information on geodesics see \ref geodesic.
00080    **********************************************************************/
00081 
00082   class Geodesic {
00083   private:
00084     typedef Math::real real;
00085     friend class GeodesicLine;
00086     friend class CassiniSoldner;
00087     static const int tauord = GEOD_TAU_ORD;
00088     static const int ntau = tauord;
00089     static const int nsig = tauord;
00090     static const int zetord = GEOD_TAU_ORD;
00091     static const int nzet = zetord;
00092     static const int etaord = GEOD_ETA_ORD;
00093     // etaCoeff is multiplied by etaFactor which is O(f), so we reduce the
00094     // order to which etaCoeff is computed by 1.
00095     static const int neta = etaord > 0 ? etaord - 1 : 0;
00096     static const unsigned maxit = 50;
00097 
00098     static inline real sq(real x) throw() { return x * x; }
00099     void Lengths(real k1, real sig12,
00100                  real ssig1, real csig1, real ssig2, real csig2,
00101                  real cbet1, real cbet2,
00102                  real& s12s, real& m12a, real& m0,
00103                  real tc[], real zc[]) const throw();
00104     static void Evolute(real R, real z, real& c, real& s) throw();
00105     void InverseStart(real sbet1, real cbet1, real sbet2, real cbet2,
00106                       real lam12, real slam12, real clam12,
00107                       real& salp1, real& calp1,
00108                       real tc[], real zc[]) const throw();
00109     real Lambda12(real sbet1, real cbet1, real sbet2, real cbet2,
00110                   real salp1, real calp1,
00111                   real& salp2, real& calp2, real& sig12,
00112                   real& ssig1, real& csig1, real& ssig2, real& csig2,
00113                   real& k1, bool diffp, real& dlam12,
00114                   real tc[], real zc[], real ec[])
00115       const throw();
00116 
00117     static const real eps2, tol0, tol1, tol2, xthresh;
00118     const real _a, _r, _f, _f1, _e2, _ep2, _n, _b;
00119     static real SinSeries(real sinx, real cosx, const real c[], int n)
00120       throw();
00121     static inline real AngNormalize(real x) throw() {
00122       // Place angle in [-180, 180).  Assumes x is in [-540, 540).
00123       return x >= 180 ? x - 360 : x < -180 ? x + 360 : x;
00124     }
00125     static inline real AngRound(real x) throw() {
00126       // The makes the smallest gap in x = 1/16 - nextafter(1/16, 0) = 1/2^57
00127       // for reals = 0.7 pm on the earth if x is an angle in degrees.  (This
00128       // is about 1000 times more resolution than we get with angles around 90
00129       // degrees.)  We use this to avoid having to deal with near singular
00130       // cases when x is non-zero but tiny (e.g., 1.0e-200).
00131       const real z = real(0.0625); // 1/16
00132       volatile real y = std::abs(x);
00133       // The compiler mustn't "simplify" z - (z - y) to y
00134       y = y < z ? z - (z - y) : y;
00135       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00136     }
00137     static inline void SinCosNorm(real& sinx, real& cosx) throw() {
00138       real r = Math::hypot(sinx, cosx);
00139       sinx /= r;
00140       cosx /= r;
00141     }
00142 
00143     // These are Maxima generated functions to provide series approximations to
00144     // the integrals for the ellipsoidal geodesic.
00145     static real tauFactorm1(real k1) throw();
00146     static void tauCoeff(real k1, real t[]) throw();
00147     static void sigCoeff(real k1, real tp[]) throw();
00148     static real zetFactorm1(real k1) throw();
00149     static void zetCoeff(real k1, real t[]) throw();
00150     static real etaFactor(real f, real k1) throw();
00151     static void etaCoeff(real f, real k1, real h[]) throw();
00152 
00153   public:
00154 
00155     /**
00156      * Constructor for a ellipsoid with equatorial radius \e a (meters) and
00157      * reciprocal flattening \e r.  Setting \e r = 0 implies \e r = inf or
00158      * flattening = 0 (i.e., a sphere).  Negative \e r indicates a prolate
00159      * ellipsoid.  An exception is thrown if \e a is not positive.
00160      **********************************************************************/
00161     Geodesic(real a, real r);
00162 
00163     /**
00164      * Perform the direct geodesic calculation.  Given a latitude, \e lat1,
00165      * longitude, \e lon1, and azimuth \e azi1 (degrees) for point 1 and a
00166      * range, \e s12 (meters) from point 1 to point 2, return the latitude, \e
00167      * lat2, longitude, \e lon2, and forward azimuth, \e azi2 (degrees) for
00168      * point 2 and the reduced length \e m12 (meters).  If \e arcmode (default
00169      * false) is set to true, \e s12 is interpreted as the arc length \e a12
00170      * (degrees) on the auxiliary sphere.  An arc length greater that 180
00171      * degrees results in a geodesic which is not a shortest path.  For a
00172      * prolate ellipsoid, an additional condition is necessary for a shortest
00173      * path: the longitudinal extent must not exceed of 180 degrees.  Returned
00174      * value is the arc length \e a12 (degrees) if \e arcmode is false,
00175      * otherwise it is the distance \e s12 (meters)
00176      **********************************************************************/
00177     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00178                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2, real& m12,
00179                       bool arcmode = false) const throw();
00180 
00181     /**
00182      * Perform the inverse geodesic calculation.  Given a latitude, \e lat1,
00183      * longitude, \e lon1, for point 1 and a latitude, \e lat2, longitude, \e
00184      * lon2, for point 2 (all in degrees), return the geodesic distance, \e s12
00185      * (meters), the forward azimuths, \e azi1 and \e azi2 (degrees) at points
00186      * 1 and 2, and the reduced length \e m12 (meters).  Returned value is the
00187      * arc length \e a12 (degrees) on the auxiliary sphere.  The routine uses
00188      * an iterative method.  If the method fails to converge, the negative of
00189      * the distances (\e s12, \e m12, and \e a12) and reverse of the azimuths
00190      * are returned.  This is not expected to happen with ellipsoidal models of
00191      * the earth.  Please report all cases where this occurs.
00192      **********************************************************************/
00193     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00194                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2, real& m12)
00195       const throw();
00196 
00197     /**
00198      * Set up to do a series of ranges.  This returns a GeodesicLine object
00199      * with point 1 given by latitude, \e lat1, longitude, \e lon1, and azimuth
00200      * \e azi1 (degrees).  Calls to GeodesicLine::Position return the
00201      * position and azimuth for point 2 a specified distance away.  Using
00202      * GeodesicLine::Position is approximately 2.1 faster than calling
00203      * Geodesic::Direct.
00204      **********************************************************************/
00205     GeodesicLine Line(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1)
00206       const throw();
00207 
00208     /**
00209      * The major radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is that value of \e a
00210      * used in the constructor.
00211      **********************************************************************/
00212     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _a; }
00213 
00214     /**
00215      * The inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is that value of \e r
00216      * used in the constructor.  A value of 0 is returned for a sphere
00217      * (infinite inverse flattening).
00218      **********************************************************************/
00219     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw() { return _r; }
00220 
00221     /**
00222      * A global instantiation of Geodesic with the parameters for the WGS84
00223      * ellipsoid.
00224      **********************************************************************/
00225     const static Geodesic WGS84;
00226   };

00228   /**
00229    * \brief A geodesic line.
00230    *
00231    * GeodesicLine facilitates the determination of a series of points on a
00232    * single geodesic.  Geodesic.Line returns a GeodesicLine object with the
00233    * geodesic defined by by \e lat1, \e lon1, and \e azi1.
00234    * GeodesicLine.Position returns the \e lat2, \e lon2, \e azi2, and \e m12
00235    * given \e s12.  An example of use of this class is:
00236    \verbatim
00237    // Print positions on a geodesic going through latitude 30,
00238    // longitude 10 at azimuth 80.  Points at intervals of 10km
00239    // in the range [-1000km, 1000km] are given.
00240    GeographicLib::GeodesicLine
00241      line(GeographicLib::Geodesic::WGS84.Line(30.0, 10.0, 80.0));
00242    double step = 10e3;
00243    for (int s = -100; s <= 100; ++s) {
00244      double lat2, lon2, azi2, m12;
00245      double s12 = s * step;
00246      line.Position(s12, lat2, lon2, azi2, m12);
00247      cout << s12 << " " << lat2 << " " << lon2 << " "
00248           << azi2 << " " << m12 << "\n";
00249    }
00250    \endverbatim
00251    * The default copy constructor and assignment operators work with this
00252    * class, so that, for example, the previous example could start
00253    \verbatim
00254    GeographicLib::GeodesicLine line;
00255    line = GeographicLib::Geodesic::WGS84.Line(30.0, 10.0, 80.0);
00256    ...
00257    \endverbatim
00258    * Similarly, a vector can be used to hold GeodesicLine objects.
00259    *
00260    * The calculations are accurate to better than 12 nm.  (See \ref geoderrors
00261    * for details.)
00262    **********************************************************************/
00263 
00264   class GeodesicLine {
00265   private:
00266     typedef Math::real real;
00267     friend class Geodesic;
00268     friend class CassiniSoldner;
00269     static const int ntau = Geodesic::ntau;
00270     static const int nsig = Geodesic::nsig;
00271     static const int nzet = Geodesic::nzet;
00272     static const int neta = Geodesic::neta;
00273 
00274     real _lat1, _lon1, _azi1;
00275     real _a, _r,  _b, _f1, _salp0, _calp0, _u2,
00276       _ssig1, _csig1, _stau1, _ctau1, _somg1, _comg1,
00277       _taufm1, _zetfm1, _etaf, _dtau1, _dzet1, _dlam1;
00278     real _tauCoeff[ntau ? ntau : 1], _sigCoeff[nsig ? nsig : 1],
00279       _zetCoeff[nzet ? nzet : 1], _etaCoeff[neta ? neta : 1];
00280 
00281     static inline real sq(real x) throw() { return x * x; }
00282     GeodesicLine(const Geodesic& g, real lat1, real lon1, real azi1)
00283       throw();
00284   public:
00285 
00286     /**
00287      * A default constructor.  If GeodesicLine::Position is called on the
00288      * resulting object, it returns immediately (without doing any
00289      * calculations).  The object should be set with a call to Geodesic::Line.
00290      * Use Init() to test whether object is still in this uninitialized state.
00291      **********************************************************************/
00292     GeodesicLine() throw() : _b(0) {};
00293 
00294     /**
00295      * Return the latitude, \e lat2, longitude, \e lon2, and forward azimuth,
00296      * \e azi2 (degrees) of the point 2 which is a distance, \e s12 (in
00297      * meters), from point 1.  Also return the reduced length \e m12 (meters).
00298      * \e s12 can be signed.  If \e arcmode (default false) is set to true, \e
00299      * s12 is interpreted as the arc length \e a12 (in degrees) on the
00300      * auxiliary sphere.  Returned value is the arc length \e a12 (degrees) if
00301      * \e arcmode is false, otherwise it is the distance \e s12 (meters).
00302      **********************************************************************/
00303     Math::real Position(real s12, real& lat2, real& lon2,
00304                         real& azi2, real &m12, bool arcmode = false)
00305       const throw();
00306 
00307     /**
00308      * Has this object been initialized so that Position can be called?
00309      **********************************************************************/
00310     bool Init() const throw() { return _b > 0; }
00311 
00312     /**
00313      * Return the latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00314      **********************************************************************/
00315     Math::real Latitude() const throw() { return Init() ? _lat1 : 0; }
00316 
00317     /**
00318      * Return the longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00319      **********************************************************************/
00320     Math::real Longitude() const throw() { return Init() ? _lon1 : 0; }
00321 
00322     /**
00323      * Return the azimuth (degrees) of the geodesic line as it passes through
00324      * point 1.
00325      **********************************************************************/
00326     Math::real Azimuth() const throw() { return Init() ? _azi1 : 0; }
00327 
00328     /**
00329      * The major radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is that value of \e a
00330      * inherited from the Geodesic object used in the constructor.
00331      **********************************************************************/
00332     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return Init() ? _a : 0; }
00333 
00334     /**
00335      * The inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is that value of \e r
00336      * inherited from the Geodesic object used in the constructor.  A value of
00337      * 0 is returned for a sphere (infinite inverse flattening).
00338      **********************************************************************/
00339     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw() { return Init() ? _r : 0; }
00340   };
